title: Access to the Neotoma Paleoecological Database Through R
text: functions available package help. represent core functions: get_site - obtain information sites Neotoma dataset (may contain multiple datasets). API get_dataset - obtain dataset metadata Neotoma. API get_download - obtain full datasets (pollen mammal) Neotoma. API compile_list - using established pollen-related taxonomies literature, take published taxon list standardize allow cross site analysis. get_contact - find contact information data contributors Neotoma. API get_publication - obtain publication information Neotoma. API get_table - return matrices corresponding one Neotoma database tables. tables get_taxa - Get taxon information Neotoma. API get_chroncontrol - Get chronological information used build age-depth model record. API

title: Access to the Neotoma Paleoecological Database Through R
text: 1.7.6: Updated API endpoints correctly point new windows API endpoint, preparation migration; Fixed help get_closest(); Changed character encoding two data tables, pollen.equiv taxon.list, made available main package using data(). 1.7.4: Bug fix: get_dataset(gpid=123) returning error, fix corrects error allow unassigned x variables. Updated allowable dataset types searching reflect larger set dataset types within Neotoma. 1.7.3: Added numeric/integer methods get_site() get_dataset() functions vector dataset siteids can passed improve general workflow methods. 1.7.2: Bugfixes, added taxa() function easily extract taxa one multiple download objects. 1.7.1: Bugfix compile_download(), single sample downloads failing compile properly, added taxa() function extract taxa lists large download objects. 1.7.0: Added plot_leaflet() allow interactive exploration downloaded Neotoma data. Integrates Neotoma Explorer. Minor bugfix get_download() allow records sent Neotoma filtered. 1.6.2: Improved basic plot() method based tests Tilia files Neotoma Holding Tank & built robust interpolation read_bacon() age models without interpolated dates can still imported. browse() now opens multiple datastes Neotoma Explorer . 1.6.1: New Stratiplot() method, using analogue package plot dataset diagrams download download_list objects, bug fixes write_agefile() new function, read_bacon(), read integrate Bacon chronologies download objects. 1.6.0: Support vector inputs gpid selection. Added get_closest() function find closest sample site. Mostly clean-reported bugs users. Revised examples faster check speed. 1.5.1: Minor fix get_dataset() site level data account datasets empty submission data. style changes code (non-functional changes) 1.5.0: extensive testing support multiple dataset types. Water chemistry datasets still unsupported. Function read.tilia() added read Tilia (http://tiliait.com) style XML files. Moved using xml2, httr jsonlite support parsing. 1.4.1: Small changes get_geochron() address bug reports improve object print methods. 1.4.0: Added plot() method datasets, sites & downloads. Fixed bug records missing chronologies.

what: Find the distribution of sites with Mammoth fossils in Neotoma
title: Access to the Neotoma Paleoecological Database Through R
text: thing
code: #  Example requires the mapdata package: library('mapdata')  #  You may use either '%' or '*' as wildcards for search terms: test <- get_dataset(taxonname='Mammuthus*')  The API call was successful, you have returned  3273 records.  site.locs <- get_site(test)  # A crude way of making the oceans blue. plot(1, type = 'n',      xlim=range(site.locs$long)+c(-10, 10),      ylim=range(site.locs$lat)+c(-10, 10),      xlab='Longitude', ylab = 'Latitude') rect(par("usr")[1],par("usr")[3],par("usr")[2],par("usr")[4],col = "lightblue") map('world',     interior=TRUE,     fill=TRUE,     col='gray',     xlim=range(site.locs$long)+c(-10, 10),     ylim=range(site.locs$lat)+c(-10, 10),     add=TRUE)  points(site.locs$long, site.locs$lat, pch=19, cex=0.5, col='red')

what: Plot the proportion of publications per year for datasets in Neotoma
title: Access to the Neotoma Paleoecological Database Through R
text: thing
code: # Requires ggplot2 library('ggplot2') library('plyr') pubs <- get_publication()  pub.years <- ldply(pubs, "[[", "meta")  ggplot(data=pub.years, aes(x = year)) +      stat_bin(aes(y=..density..*100, position='dodge'), binwidth=1) +      theme_bw() +      ylab('Percent of Publications') +      xlab('Year of Publication') +      scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0.1)) +      scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(min(pub.years$year, na.rm=TRUE), 2014, by=20))

title: Function to bind objects together into a longer object. â€” bind
code: if (FALSE) { #  Search for sites with "Thuja" pollen that are older than 8kyr BP and #  that are on the west coast of North America: t8kyr.poa <- get_dataset(taxonname="Thuja*",                           loc=c(-150, 20, -100, 60), ageyoung = 8000) t8kyr.canis <- get_dataset(taxonname="Canis*",                             loc=c(-150, 20, -100, 60), ageyoung = 8000)  t8kyr.co_site <- bind(t8kyr.poa, t8kyr.canis) plot(t8kyr.co_site)  #### # We want to look at four different dataset types across a forest-prairie  # boundary: dataset_types <- c("ostracode surface sample",                    "water chemistry",                    "diatom surface sample",                    "pollen surface sample")  # Run the `get_dataset` function for each of the different dataset types  dataset_lists <- lapply(dataset_types,                            function(x) {                              get_dataset(datasettype=x,                                          loc = c(-100,43,-92,48))                                         })  # Using do.call here to make sure that I don't have to split the list out. new_datasets <- do.call(bind, dataset_lists)  # And voila! plot(new_datasets)  }

title: Compile download objects â€” compile_downloads
code: if (FALSE) { #  Search for sites with "Thuja" pollen that are older than 8kyr BP and #  that are on the west coast of North America: t8kyr.datasets <- get_dataset(taxonname='Thuja*',                                loc=c(-150, 20, -100, 60),                                ageyoung = 8000)  #  Returns 3 records (as of 04/04/2013), get dataset for the first record,  #  Gold Lake Bog. thuja.sites <- get_download(t8kyr.datasets)  gold.p25 <- compile_taxa(thuja.sites, 'P25')  all.gold <- compile_downloads(gold.p25)  pollen.sums <- rowSums(all.gold[,11:ncol(all.gold)], na.rm=TRUE)  plot(x = all.gold$age,       y = all.gold$Cupressaceae.Taxaceae / pollen.sums,       col = all.gold$site.name,      pch = 19)  }

code: if (FALSE) { #  The point of pulling chronology tables is to re-build or examine the  #  chronological information that was used to build the age-depth model for  #  the core.  You can do this by hand, but the `write_agefile` function works  #  with `download` objects directly.  three_pines <- get_download(get_dataset(get_site("Three Pines Bog"),                                          datasettype = "pollen")) pines_chron <- get_chroncontrol(three_pines)  # Spline interpolation: model <- smooth.spline(x = pines_chron[[1]]$chron.control$depth,                        y = pines_chron[[1]]$chron.control$age)                         new_ages <- predict(model, x = three_pines[[1]]$sample.meta$depth)  }

title: Get contact information. â€” get_contact
text: contactid Contact ID numerical value associated Neotoma Contact table's numerical Contact ID. contactname character string indicating data contributors' project, organization personal name.  May partial string can include wildcards. contactstatus current status contact.  Possible values include: active, deceased, defunct, extant, inactive, retired, unknown. familyname character string.  Full partial string indicating contact's last name.

title: Get contact information. â€” get_contact
text: function takes parameters defined user returns list    contact information supplied Neotoma Paleoecological Database.    user may define none possible fields.  function contains    data checks defined parameter. function returns either single item class "try-error" describing    reason failure (either mis-defined parameters error Neotoma API),    table contacts, rows corresponding number individual    contacts returned Neotoma API.  row entry includes following parameters: contact.name Full name person, last name first (e.g. "Simpson, George Gaylord") name organization project (e.g. "Great Plains Flora Association"). contact.status Current status person, organization, project. Field links ContactStatuses lookup table. family.name Family surname name person. leading.initials Leading initials given forenames without spaces (e.g. "G.G."). given.names Given forenames person (e.g. "George Gaylord"). Initials spaces used full given names known (e.g. "G. G"). suffix Suffix person's name (e.g. "Jr.", "III"). title person's title (e.g. "Dr.", "Prof.", "Prof. Dr"). phone Telephone number. fax Fax number. email Email address. url Universal Resource Locator, Internet World Wide Web address. address Full mailing address. notes Free form notes comments person, organization, project. contact.id Unique database record identifier contact. alias.id ContactID person's current name. AliasID different ContactID, ContactID refers person's former name.

text: details use parameters can obtained  http://wnapi.neotomadb.org/doc/resources/datasets. list class `dataset_list`, item corresponding individual record.    Searches return items result NULL value returned.    Otherwise list item (dataset record) includes following components: dataset.id Unique database record identifier dataset. dataset.name Name dataset; commonly used. CollUnitHandle Code name Collection Unit dataset associated. code may 10 characters. Data frequently distributed Collection Unit, Handle used file names. CollUnitID Unique database record identifier collection unit. CollType collection type. Types include cores, sections, excavations, animal middens. DatasetType dataset type, : geochronologic, loss--ignition, pollen, plant macrofossils, vertebrate fauna, etc. AgeOldest oldest sample ages (calendar years present) dataset. AgeYoungest youngest sample ages (calendar years present) dataset. SubDates array objects describe dataset submission events.  multiple submissions occurred table. DatasetPIs array objects describe Principal Investigators associated dataset. Site object describing site dataset samples taken.

title: Function to return full download records using sites, datasets, or dataset IDs. â€” get_download
code: if (FALSE) { #  Search for sites with "Pseudotsuga" pollen that are older than 8kyr BP and #  that are roughly within western British Columbia: t8kyr.datasets <- get_dataset(taxonname='*Picea*', loc=c(-90, 41, -89, 44),                               ageold = 20000, ageyoung=10000)  #  Returns 20 records (as of 04/04/2013), get the dataset for all records: pollen.records <- get_download(t8kyr.datasets)  #  Standardize the taxonomies for the different records using the WS64 taxonomy. compiled.sites <- compile_taxa(pollen.records, list.name='WS64')  #  Extract the Pseudotsuga curves for the sites: get.curve <- function(x, taxa) {                if (taxa %in% colnames(x$counts)) {                  count <- x$counts[,taxa]/rowSums(x$counts, na.rm=TRUE)                } else {                  count <- rep(0, nrow(x$count))                }                data.frame(site = x$dataset$site.data$site.name,                age = x$sample.meta$age,                count = count)              }  curves <- do.call(rbind.data.frame,                   lapply(compiled.sites, get.curve, taxa = 'Larix/Pseudotsuga'))  #  For illustration, remove the sites with no Pseudotsuga occurance: curves <- curves[curves$count > 0, ]  smooth.curve <- predict(loess(sqrt(count)~age, data=curves),                         data.frame(age=seq(20000, 0, by = -100)))  plot(sqrt(count) ~ age, data = curves,      ylab = '% Pseudotsuga/Larix', xlab='Calibrated Years BP', pch=19,      col=rgb(0.1, 0.1, 0.1, 0.1), xlim=c(0, 20000)) lines(seq(20000, 0, by = -100), smooth.curve, lwd=2, lty=2, col=2)  #  This figure shows us an apparent peak in Larix/Pseudotsuga pollen in the #  early-Holocene that lends support to a warmer, drier early-Holocene in #  western North America. }

code: if (FALSE) { #  Search for the sites around Marion Lake, BC.  I want to find sites within  #  about 1km.  marion <- get_site(sitename = "Marion Lake*")  marion_close <- get_closest(marion, n = 10, buffer = 1)  #  Returns 116 records (as of 13/07/2015).  These are the pollen records though,  #  we want the sites: geochron.records <- get_geochron(marion_close)  #  We want to extract all the radiocarbon ages from the records:  get_ages <- function(x){   any.ages <- try(x[[2]]$age[x[[2]]$age.type == 'Radiocarbon years BP'])   if(is(any.ages, 'try-error')) output <- NA   if(!is(any.ages, 'try-error')) output <- unlist(any.ages)   output }  radio.chron <- unlist(sapply(geochron.records, get_ages))  hist(radio.chron[radio.chron<40000], breaks=seq(0, 25000, by = 1000),      main = 'Radiocarbon dates for Pseudotsuga records',      xlab = 'Radiocarbon date (14C years before 1950)') }

code: if (FALSE) { # Download the record for Lake O' Pines: lake_o_dl <- get_download(15925)  # This assumes that you have Bacon installed in a folder and have # set it to your working directory.  write_agefile(lake_o_dl[[1]], path = ".", chronology = 1,                corename = "LAKEPINES", cal.prog = 'Bacon')   source("Bacon.R")   # These defaults just help the core run quickly, they're not  # neccesarily good parameters.  Bacon("LAKEPINES", acc.mean = 10,        thick = 50, depths.file = TRUE,        suggest = FALSE, ask = FALSE)  lake_o_dl <- read_bacon("LAKEPINES", add = TRUE,                          download = download, sections = 17)  }
